feed.title: NewsTracker: georgia execution
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Lawyers: Georgia waffles on execution with cloudy drug
entry.summary: ATLANTA (AP) - Georgia officials waffled on whether to proceed with an execution when the lethal injection drug was discovered to have a cloudy appearance, according to a court filing, and one expert said their decision to postpone it was the right move.

entry.title: Georgia halts execution of state's only female death row inmate
entry.summary:
Gissendaner's execution by injection was reset for Monday night at a prison in Jackson, Ga., after a winter storm prompted state officials to postpone it last week.

The Georgia Supreme Court on Monday afternoon turned down Gissendaner's request for a stay of execution.

entry.title: Georgia postpones its 1st execution of a woman in 70 years after concerns about injection drug
entry.summary: Georgia and other death penalty states have bought execution drugs from compounding pharmacies in recent years after pharmaceutical companies stopped selling to U.S. prisons.

entry.title: Concerns over drug prompt delay of Georgia woman's execution
entry.summary: (AP) - Citing concerns about the drug to be used in a lethal injection, corrections officials in Georgia postponed the execution of the state's only female death row inmate for the second time in a week.

entry.title: Georgia halts execution of state's only female death row inmate: newspaper
entry.summary: "Within the hours leading up to the scheduled execution, the Execution Team performed the necessary checks. At that time, the drugs appeared cloudy," Georgia Department of Corrections spokeswoman Gwendolyn Hogan said in a statement.

entry.title: Execution of Georgia woman postponed; problem with drug
entry.summary: Georgia law prohibits the release of any identifying information about the source of execution drugs or any entity involved in an execution.

entry.title: Execution of Georgia woman postponed; problem with drug
entry.summary:
(AP) - Georgia postponed its first execution of a woman in 70 years late Monday, as officials cited problems with the lone drug that would be used for the lethal injection.

The drug, pentobarbital, had a cloudy appearance, prompting officials to call a pharmacist and then out of an "abundance of caution" to postpone the execution, said Georgia Department of Corrections spokeswoman Gwendolyn Hogan.

entry.title: Georgia woman trying to avoid execution for husband's murder
